Description: Scarab carved from stone; back relatively well-shaped with clypeus, head, and prothorax; elytra indicated by four grooves; underside incised with motif arranged vertically comprising to left name of Wahibre in a cartouche, to right raised cobra, surmounted by winged sun and above neb-basket sign; pierced longitudinally; traces of pale green glaze; modern glue on back.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The name of Wahibra appears on a number of scarabs discovered in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII no. 185 and 187; Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII no. 27, 29 and no. 65). The inscription Wah-ib-ra, the prenomen of Psamtek I or nomen of Apries, is rather frequent on scarabs of the 26th dynasty (for example: Petrie 1889, pl. 62; Fraser 1900, 46, 374; Newberry 1906, pl. XXXVIII, 10; Hall 1913, 251, nos. 2506-2508; Petrie 1917, LV 26.1,19/ 21; Vercoutter 1945, 95, 5; Matouk 1971, 200, 835/ 221, 871-872; Hornung and Staehelin 1976, 285, 469; Ben-Tor 1989, 79, 13; Jaeger 1993, 116; Magnarini 2004, 421, 11.77). A glazed composition scarab from Naukratis presents a relatively similar design, albeit the winged sun is replaced by an upside-down neb-sign (Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.854). A very similar design can be found on Menkheperra scarabs (see for example Jaeger 1982, § 419, ill. 223). Ben-Tor, D. 1989.
